Alkene oxidation is an important industrial process that produces considerable quantities of commodity chemicals, notably ethylene oxide and propylene oxide. However, typical thermal oxidation processes are characterized by harsh reaction conditions and limited selectivity. Thus, electrochemical alternatives with enhanced product selectivity emerge as promising solutions with the possibility of using renewable input energy sources. Herein, we discuss strategies to improve the selectivity of alkene electrooxidation, specifically focusing on the regulation of the geometric and electronic structures of electrocatalysts, as well as the application of mediated indirect oxidation. Furthermore, we also provide an overview of the current challenges and problems requiring further investigation in improving industrial feasibility of electrochemical alkene oxidation. Graphical Abstract Electrocatalysis offers a more efficient means to selectively oxidize alkenes under mild reaction conditions, suppressing overoxidation to carbon dioxide. This article provides an overview of recent advances in alkene selective electrooxidation, encompassing direct oxidation and indirect oxidation. Keywords Alkene oxidation Electrocatalysis Overoxidation Electronic structure Indirect oxidation 1 Introduction Alkenes, such as ethylene and propylene, comprise a class of important industrial feedstock in the production of value-added chemicals. Selective oxidation of alkenes can yield major chemical intermediates such as ethylene oxide (EO) and propylene oxide (PO). EO and PO are widely used in the polymer industry for fabrication of polyethylene oxide (PEO), polypropylene oxide (PPO) and polyurethane (PU). Additionally, EO and PO also serve as raw materials to produce ethylene carbonate (EC) and propylene carbonate (PC), which are common electrolyte solvents for lithium ion batteries [1], as well as ethylene glycol (EG) and propylene glycol (PG), often used as antifreeze agents [2,3]. Moreover, EG and PG are versatile building blocks for organic synthesis and have seen significant application in pharmaceutical industry. With such industrial importance, the global market sizes of EO and PO in 2022 are estimated at USD 48.9 billion and USD 22.9 billion respectively, and are expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 4.1% and 5.5% from 2022 to 2030 [4,5]. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to be the largest and fastest-growing market for EO and PO during the forecast period, owing to the rapid industrialization and urbanization in countries such as China and India. In chemical industry, epoxides such as EO and PO are mainly produced through chlorohydrin process, hydroperoxide processes and direct oxidation of alkenes [6,7]. Specifically, EO is mainly thermochemically synthesized on α-Al2O3-supported Ag catalyst while introducing O2 as the oxidant at 200–300 °C and 1–3 MPa, but this process usually results in certain amount of CO2 by-product [8,9]. PO can also be prepared by Ag-catalyzed reaction, but the selectivity of PO product is limited due to generation of acrolein by-product via the allylic hydrogen stripping (AHS) in addition of total oxidation to CO2. Therefore, to suppress acrolein generation, the research on thermal epoxidation is focused mostly on annihilating acidic sites, tuning active site geometry and modifying surface with alkaline metals or halide ions [10]. Despite the relative maturity of industrial partial alkene oxidation, the catalytic reactions generally need to be conducted under high temperature and pressure, making them energy-intensive. Additionally, fossil-fuel-powered systems are typically used to maintain a stable temperature profile to suppress thermal runaway in this highly exothermic reaction. Furthermore, under high temperature and pressure, alkenes are also susceptible to C–C bond cleavage, which results in overoxidized CO2 product, reducing reaction selectivity and economic benefit while further increasing carbon emissions [10,11]. Electrocatalysis, with excellent economic efficiency and environmental friendliness, can intrinsically avoid harsh reaction conditions and thus, increase the reaction selectivity. In an electrolyzer, as shown in Fig. 1 , alkenes are selectively oxidized at anodic compartment to generate oxygenated products, and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is often paired as the cathodic half-reaction, from which hydrogen fuel is produced. Powering the reaction electrically can potentially reduce reliance on fossil fuels with the use of electricity generated from renewable sources [12]. Moreover, the energy conversion efficiency of electrocatalysis is much higher than traditional thermochemical methods because electricity can directly drive charge transfer in the catalytic system. Furthermore, the electric double layer formed between the electrode and the electrolyte under electric field provides heterointerface that can be delicately modified and regulated. However, there are also some disadvantages of electrocatalysis that should be noticed. Firstly, the cost of electrochemical devices is not trivial. Due to the relatively low current densities of the electrocatalytic systems reported so far, a larger electrolyzer area is required to match the desired yield, resulting in even higher capital cost. Moreover, electricity cost should also be considered especially if renewable energy is used to power the electrocatalytic system since the overall production cost becomes sensitive to electricity generation cost. To further understand alkene electrooxidation, its possible reaction mechanisms, as exemplified by ethylene epoxidation, are proposed in Scheme 1 . The first mechanism (Scheme 1(a)) involves coupling of two surface species, namely adsorbed alkenes and oxygenated species. Ethylene adsorbs on the surface of electrode, while water dissociates to form surface oxygenated species, namely O and OH. Oxygenated species will react with adsorbed ethylene, producing oxametallacycle intermediates. After ring closing, ethylene oxide product desorbs from the electrode surface. Other possible mechanisms presented in Schemes 1(b), (c) involve the coupling of surface species and free species from electrolyte. In the case of Scheme 1(b), surface oxygen atom reacts directly with diffused ethylene to produce ethylene oxide, while in the case of Scheme 1(c), the ethylene adsorbed on an active site (which could be a metal atom) can be attacked by free OH− to produce ethylene oxide through ring closing. However, there are also many side reactions besides the epoxidation mechanisms discussed. Hence, the product selectivity problem still exists in electrocatalytic reactions. While the production of unintended liquid phase by-products with certain value can be resolved through separation by distillation or other techniques, overoxidation of alkene produces CO2, resulting in economic loss. Hence, preventing overoxidation is crucial in ensuring economic efficiency of alkene electrooxidation. The reported products of electrocatalytic oxidation of ethylene, propylene and some other alkenes are summarized in Scheme 1. Economically, the molecules in blue in Scheme 1 (e.g., EG, EO, PG and PO) are the products with relatively high demand, often being the target products in various research works, while the molecules in black (e.g., formic acid) are generally by-products with acceptable economic values and CO2 (colored red) is the undesired overoxidation product. Based on the change of oxidation state, the products can be classified into two categories, namely those derived from one oxygen addition (1 Ox.) and those from two oxygen additions (2 Ox.). Generally, higher degree of oxygenation and dehydrogenation results in higher oxidation state of carbon, increasing the susceptibility of the molecule to C–C bond cleavage which generates CO2. In terms of reactive sites, ethylene and propylene are different as ethylene has only one reactive site (namely the C=C double bond), while propylene has two reactive sites, which are the C=C double bond and allylic methyl group. Among the products of propylene oxidation, it can be inferred that allyl alcohol, acrolein and acrylic acid are generated from the C–H activation of the allylic methyl group, while acetone, PO and PG are produced from the oxygenation of the double bond, and the formation of hydroxyacetone may involve the oxidation of both vinyl and allylic methyl groups. Consequently, unlike the case of ethylene oxidation, the regulation of the C–H and C=C reaction routes should be considered when designing the electrocatalytic system for propylene oxidation. Given the promising prospect and scientific challenges, selective alkene electrooxidation has raised extensive attention. In the last century, pristine reactors had been designed for selective alkene epoxidation, using electrochemically generated halogen as oxidant. However, these early technologies had low current efficiency (~10%). Nonetheless, Sargent's group has recently improved the device and catalyst design, realizing a high faradaic efficiency of 70% [13]. This promising advance has also sparked a wave of alkene oxidation research that mainly focuses on improving product selectivity. To the best of our knowledge, the review article by Gong et al. [14] is the only recent one that discusses about advances in electrochemically aided alkene epoxidation. While they have successfully summarized these advancements by categorizing them based on oxidant species, there is a need for further clarification on the issue of product selectivity. Additionally, it is important to pay attention to other potential products in alkene electrooxidation. Hence, herein, we discuss possible strategies to improve the selectivity of electrooxidation of alkenes, including the regulation of both geometric and electronic structure of the catalysts for direct oxidation, along with the mediated indirect oxidation. Overlooked aspects and problems to be resolved are also highlighted. 2 Direct electrooxidation of alkenes The direct electrooxidation of alkenes refers to the direct electrochemical oxidation of alkenes at the electrode/electrolyte interface without intervention of external mediators. To avoid overoxidation of alkenes in direct electrooxidation, various suppression strategies have been developed, typically including geometric structure modification of the catalyst to isolate the reactive sites through surface poisoning or increasing surface coverage of reactants (or substrates) and regulating the electronic structure of the catalyst surface. 2.1 Modulating available active sites of catalysts In the industrial Ag-catalyzed ethylene oxidation to EO, Cl− is often added as a surface poisoning agent to poison the acidic centers on the surface and inhibit the hydrolysis of EO to acetaldehyde. In addition, Cl− can competitively adsorb on the Ag catalytic surface where O2 would typically adsorb and dissociate, improving the electrophilicity of adsorbed O atoms [10]. The surface poisoning strategy applied in thermocatalytic alkene oxidation is also applied in its electrocatalytic counterpart. Notably, Jirkovský et al. [15] found that the addition of 0.3 mol L-1 Cl- can promote epoxidation of ethylene on RuO2 catalyst and suppress overoxidation. In their proposed model, the terminal oxygens on the RuO2 surface were considered as the active sites. They argue that both overoxidation of ethylene to CO2 and O2 evolution reaction (OER) are diatomic processes that require two adjacent reactive sites, while the reaction mechanism of ethylene epoxidation, similar to that on the surface of Ag, involves single-site adsorption on terminal O of RuO2. By poisoning the reactive sites of RuO2 with Cl−, the Cl− surface coverage increases and the possibility of ethylene double-site adsorption decreases as illustrated in Fig. 2(a) , suppressing ethylene overoxidation and OER. Since single-site adsorption of ethylene is expected to be affected by the surface coverage to a smaller degree, the selectivity of the epoxidation reaction is deemed to have improved. However, the high selectivity of the epoxidation reaction could not be reliably demonstrated as the work could not satisfactorily explain the quantitative discrepancy between the notable increase in ethylene consumption rate and the relatively marginal increase in detection of oxygenated products (or intermediates). This means that the presence of other ethylene consumption pathways could not be discounted despite Jirkovský's success in suppressing the overoxidation pathway. The suppression of overoxidation reactions by Cl- have been further discussed by Cheng's research group [16] through theoretical analysis, resulting in the proposal of a different adsorption state of Cl− in the presence of ethylene. They believe that the direct adsorption of Cl− on RuO2 lattice oxygen can hardly occur due to the relatively high potential barrier. However, they argued that by certain degree of ethylene overoxidation on the surface of the catalyst, bridge-adsorbed *OCClO* configuration will be formed (Fig. 2(b)), which comprises of two adjacent oxygen sites and further isolates the catalytic reactive sites. When a certain number of adjacent oxygen atoms are poisoned by the chloride intermediates, the isolated free oxygen sites will be dedicated for the partial oxidation, suppressing overoxidation as illustrated in Fig. 2(c). Chorkendorff's group demonstrated that the increment of surface coverage of organic species formed in situ also affects the distribution of exposed active sites, and consequently, affects the selectivity of the epoxidation reaction in a way similar to the poisoning and isolating effect of Cl− [17]. Particularly, porous Pd catalyst has exhibited its ability in electrocatalytic oxidation of propylene to acrolein while avoiding overoxidation and improving Coulombic efficiency. The experimental and theoretical analyses indicate that at a low surface coverage of organic species, the methyl group of propylene undergoes C–H activation to generate carbene-like surface adsorption species and the double bond of propylene interacts with the adjacent active site, which may cause bridge-like adsorption of propylene, followed by C–C bond cleavage and overoxidation. However, when the surface coverage on Pd increases and the active sites are occupied by dissociatively adsorbed CH x and the intentionally introduced CO, part of the active sites are isolated, preventing bridge-like adsorption of propylene and the subsequent overoxidation as described in Fig. 2(d). In both Jirkovský's and Chorkendorff's works, electrochemical-mass spectroscopy (EC-MS) is used to provide real-time information of the consumption of alkene reactants and the generation of oxidation intermediates and products to help the understanding of the effect of the modulation of active sites. With isotope labelling, more mechanistic information can be obtained, for example, by determining the oxygen sources of the oxidation reaction. In addition, although the proposed geometric effect of available active sites can reasonably explain the selectivity improvement, other possible explanations cannot be excluded with certainty. For instance, due to the nonuniformity of catalyst surface, both moderately electrophilic sites preferring selective oxidation and excessively electrophilic sites preferring overoxidation may exist simultaneously. Thus, the introduction of Cl− or other nucleophilic intermediates may tend to poison the excessively electrophilic sites and increase the total selectivity. More experimental evidence is required to verify this explanation, which can also reveal the significance of the electronic structure of the catalyst. 2.2 Modulating electronic structure of catalysts Electrocatalytic alkene epoxidation typically occurs via one of the two reaction pathways, namely oxygen-correlated pathway and hydroxyl-correlated pathway (Fig. 3(a) ). The former, using H2O as sole oxygen source, is called oxygen atom transfer (OAT) process, which has been widely applicable to electrochemical synthesis (e.g., sulfoxidation, nitrite oxidation and arsenite oxidation) [18] and may also be observed in alkene epoxidation. After dissociation and dehydration of H2O adsorbate, oxygen atoms are generated on the surface of the catalysts and transferred to the substrate molecules (e.g., cyclohexene and cyclooctene). As some of the intermediates in this pathway resemble those in OER, it is not surprising that OER can also be catalyzed on the surface of these OAT catalysts, such as those reported for cyclooctene oxidation including Mn3O4 [19], Fe2O3 [18], RuO2 [20] and gold [21]. Given that the surface oxygen atom is the critical intermediate of OAT reactions, it is plausible to speculate that tuning the electronic properties of the surface oxygen may suppress the undesired OER and improve the selectivity towards epoxidation. Manthiram's group presented electrocatalytic oxidation of cyclooctene into cyclooctene oxide in a cell consisting of manganese oxide nanoparticles catalyst on carbon paper as anode for OAT reactions and platinum as cathode for HER [19]. Faradaic efficiency (FE) of this cell is only about 30%, which is attributed to cyclooctene overoxidation into cyclooctanone at higher potentials (about 2.0 V versus Standard Hydrogen Electrode (SHE)) and OER. From kinetic analysis, they concluded that the oxygen replenishment on the reduced Mn(II) sites is the rate-determining step (Fig. 3(b)). Based on these findings, they decorated iridium on manganese oxide nanoparticles to optimize the electronic properties of surface oxygen (Fig. 3(c)) by facilitating Mn oxidation in MnO x under increasing anodic applied potential and increasing the electrophilicity of ligand oxygen [22]. As a result, selectivity of epoxidation increased as reflected by the increase of FE to 46%, with cyclooctene oxidation partial current density of 10.5 mA cm−2. Another way of improving reaction selectivity of epoxidation is by modification of interfaces. For example, upon modification of catalyst-support interface, RuO2 supported by N-doped carbon was reported for electrochemical cyclooctene oxide synthesis with selectivity of more than 99% and FE of above 79% [20]. In this work, the N-doping of the carbon support and its subsequent contact with the metallic RuO2 nanocrystals have resulted in electron enrichment of RuO2, promoting the capture of cyclooctene substrate molecules, suppressing OER and improving the selectivity towards epoxidation. Meanwhile, when the hydrophobic tetrabutylammonium ions (TBA+) is used as supporting salt cation instead of Li+ and Na+ in electrochemical cyclooctene epoxidation on gold in acetonitrile-water electrolyte, sacrificial metallic Au dissolution occurred at low potential of about 1.46 V versus SHE, enabling homogenous catalysis of the reaction by dissolved Au+ in absence of OER despite the dissatisfactory catalytic efficiency [21]. This is because in the presence of both cyclooctene and TBA+, the catalyst-electrolyte interface is so hydrophobic that Au dissolution is favored over formation of surface gold oxide that would have occurred in a hydrophilic interface. Nonetheless, the substrate molecules of OAT reactions are usually confined to cyclic alkenes with large rings, long-chain aliphatic alkenes and aromatic alkenes, while ethylene and propylene can hardly be oxidized through OAT pathways due to their low polarity and nucleophilicity. In addition, although H2O serves as the usual oxygen donor, acetonitrile, which is flammable and toxic, is employed as solvent. As an alternative to OAT pathways, a hydroxyl correlated pathway (Fig. 4(a) ) is also proposed, in which overoxidation can be impeded and partial alkene oxidation can be facilitated by adjusting the binding energy of hydroxyl species on the surface of electrocatalysts. For instance, Ke et al. [23] reported the different propylene reactivity on distinct Ag3PO4 electrocatalysts with different distribution of exposed facets. Firstly, they synthesized Ag3PO4 cubic crystals, rhombic dodecahedral crystals and tetrahedral crystals with more (100), (110) and (111) exposed crystal planes respectively by adjusting the molar ratio of the reactants and changing the reaction solvent, and the experimental results show that both the catalytic activity and coulombic efficiency of the cubic Ag3PO4 are the highest among them. From theoretical analysis, the reaction pathways correlated with hydroxyl intermediates have lower energy barriers compared with those correlated with surface oxygen (Fig. 4(b)), and thus the reactivity of surface OH species is higher. Hydroxyl species, which is generated from H2O adsorption and dissociation on the Ag3PO4 surface, couples with the adsorbed propylene molecules to form oxametallacycle intermediate (PrOH*) while overcoming the largest reaction barrier through the first transition state (TS1), which is the lowest on (100) facets. After deprotonation and atomic rearrangement, PO is generated and desorbed. In this reaction pathway, the lower *OH binding energy of the (100) facet, which is the result of the low Ag d-band center relative to Fermi level and the little overlap between Ag d band and O p orbitals in *OH, corresponds to the higher energy level of hydroxyl species and lowers the TS1-related energy barrier of the rate-determining step. From the Bader charge analysis, the polarization of propylene is also the largest on (100) facets of Ag3PO4, enabling a more facile breaking of symmetric π bonds and facilitating C–O bond formation. This work demonstrates the possibility of tuning the binding energy of hydroxyl species with the tuning of the crystal facet distribution of the catalysts. Sargent's group [24] also reported the effect of hydroxyl binding energy on the catalytic activity and FE of electrochemical ethylene oxidation (with EG as the major product) on Pd nanostructured dendritic catalyst (Pd DNT) and PdO·H2O. When the potential of about 1.3 V versus SHE was applied in the cell where ethylene-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 NaClO4 was used as the electrolyte, it was noticed that an activation process occurred on both catalysts, in which the current decreased sharply for a period of time before increasing and equilibrating at a relatively high current. This activation would repeat itself once the electrolyte is replaced and with electrochemical redox analysis, it has been proposed that this process is related to the gradual increase of OH surface coverage that promoted EG production. Through density functional theory (DFT) calculations on a PdO (100) slab, the transition from *C2H4OH + OH (State IV) to *C2H4(OH)2 (State V) is identified as the most probable rate-determining step (Fig. 4(c)). It has also been theoretically determined that using doping the catalyst with Au can reduce the free energy change of this step, and this has been experimentally verified with Au-doped Pd DNT demonstrating average FE for EG production of 80% and partial current density of partial current density of 5.7 mA cm−2. This has demonstrated the effect of reducing OH binding energy on improving OH reactivity and promoting partial oxidation of alkenes. From the abovementioned work, one might expect Au to have better alkene oxidation selectivity than Pd, but an earlier work [25] showed the occurrence of severe overoxidation of ethylene on Au surface (especially after the reduction of surface gold oxide) with a large amount of CO2 produced during the reaction. This may be attributed to the excessively low OH binding energy on the Au surface, causing the low OH coverage on the Au surface and resulting in difficulty in coupling adsorbed ethylene with hydroxyl, enabling catalytic overoxidation by Au to generate CO2. From the above analysis, it could be inferred that a volcano trend exists between binding energy of OH and electrochemical activity of alkene partial oxidation. Excessively low binding energy leads to insufficient OH species and reduced probability of ethylene-hydroxyl coupling, while excessively high binding energy causes low reactivity by elevating coupling barrier, both of which result in overoxidation and CO2 generation. From the prior discussion, it can be inferred that both the availability and reactivity of the surface oxygenated species are of great importance for improving reaction selectivity. Avoiding overoxidation by modulating the available active site by introducing Cl− additive is more facile compared to modulating the electronic structures of the catalyst through modifications during synthesis. However, there might be a trade-off between alkene electrooxidation activity and selectivity when available active sites are modulated since the increase in selectivity arising from blockage of active site typically occurs concurrently with reduction in catalytic activity. Thus, tuning the intrinsic electronic properties of catalysts is more favorable in simultaneously improving both activity and selectivity. Nonetheless, the effects of the electronic properties of the surface oxygenated species on activity and selectivity of alkene electrooxidation have to be clarified through further research. 3 Introducing redox mediator Although the selectivity of alkene electrooxidation has been improved by tuning available active sites and electronic structures of the electrocatalysts, its current density is still unsatisfactory due to severe side reactions at high voltage. Hence, indirect oxidation (Fig. 5(a) ), in which the oxidants used to oxidize alkenes are generated in-situ from redox mediators electrochemically, has gained much attention. 3.1 Halide-mediated system With halide ions being a common mediator reported by many researchers in the last century [27–30]. Sargent's research group further improved the efficiency of this strategy by assembling a flow cell illustrated in Fig. 5(b) using Pt as the anode, Ni foam as the cathode, 1 mol L−1 KCl solution as the electrolytes, and anion exchange membranes as separator to separate catholyte and anolyte [13]. The reactions are listed as follow: Anode: 2Cl− → Cl2 + 2e− Cl2 + H2O ⇌ HOCl + HCl C2H4 + HOCl → HOCH2CH2Cl Cathode: 2H2O + 2e− → H2 + 2OH− Mixing step: HOCH2CH2Cl + OH− → C2H4O + Cl− + H2O HCl + OH− → Cl− + H2O Overall: C2H4 + H2O → C2H4O + H2 In chlorine evolution reaction (CER), the chloride ion is first oxidized into chlorine which then is disproportionated to produce hypochlorous acid and hydrochloric acid in the solution. Then, hypochlorous acid reacts with ethylene to produce ethylene chlorohydrin (HOCH2CH2Cl). The accumulation of hydrochloric acid from the disproportionation of chlorine in the anolyte reduces its pH, while water is continuously electrolyzed producing OH− in the catholyte. When the acidic anolyte and basic catholyte are mixed downstream, OH− ions from the catholyte will either neutralize H+ from the anolyte or react with ethylene chlorohydrin to promote regeneration of Cl− and release of EO. At constant current of 300 mA cm−2 in 1.0 mol L−1 KCl (with ethylene-saturation in anolyte), the FE of ethylene-to-EO oxidation reached 70% while the selectivity to EO reached 97%, with no CO2 detected. This system was demonstrated to be applicable to propylene epoxidation with FE of about 70%. To enhance energy utilization efficiency and consequently boost economic benefits, the authors conducted further optimization of electrolyte concentration, electrocatalyst, and current density. In optimization of electrolyte concentration, an increment of the concentration of Cl− can theoretically increase the conductivity of the solution, thereby promoting the kinetics of the electrochemical reaction. However, excessively high Cl− concentration is not conducive to the disproportionation reaction, which may reduce the FE of the system. Therefore, the optimal KCl concentration was found to be 2 mol L−1. In addition, it is also necessary to select an appropriate current density since the energy utilization efficiency would be reduced if the current density is too large due to the high overpotential required. However, if the current density is too small, a larger electrode surface area will be required in industrial production. Therefore, it was concluded that the optimal current density is 500 mA cm−2 when IrO2-loaded Ti mesh is used at the anode coupled with Pd foil counter electrode. In an attempt to recycle CO2 into a valuable commodity chemical and replacing ethylene feedstock with CO2, they integrated a membrane-electrode assembly (MEA) system that consists of Cu nanoparticle/Cu/polytetrafluoroethylene (Cu NP/Cu/PTFE) cathode for CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and IrO2-loaded Ti mesh anode for OER with a direct output gas pathway to ethylene-to-EO flow cell. However, the FE of EO production in the flow cell of 45% is not satisfying. Thus, further improvement of the electrocatalyst was made by loading barium oxide on IrO2 [31]. The presence of BaO x on the optimized 3 wt% BaO x /IrO2 suppresses the cleavage side reaction (or deprotonation) of HOCl and increase the ethylene-to-EO FE to 90% with a selectivity up to 98%. In the second chamber that catalyzed conversion of ethylene to EO through CER, the cathodic reaction was changed from HER to oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), lowering the theoretical reaction potential from 1.36 to 0.13 V and thus saving the input energy. Consequently, the integrated system exhibits a CO2-to-EO FE of ~35% and a full-cell energy efficiency (EE) of 36% at 100 mA cm−2. Given the abundance of chloride ions in seawater, Chung et al. [26] presented a chlorine-mediated ethylene oxidation system in natural seawater by using Co3O4 nanoparticles as anode for production of Cl2 through CER and a Pt foil as cathode for HER, demonstrating FE of 71% towards ethylene oxidation products, most of which being 2-chloroethanol that can be chemically converted into EO. This FE that almost doubled the one in phosphate-buffered 0.6 mol L−1 NaCl + 1.35 mmol L−1 NaClO4 despite having similar partial current densities was attributed to the suppression of OER by Mg2+ in the seawater. Additionally, the introduction of ethylene feedstock has affected CER kinetics as seen from the increase in the Tafel slope from ~40 to ~65 mV dec−1, indicating a change in the rate-determining step (RDS) from the electrochemical formation of chloronium intermediate (*Cl+) to Cl recombination (Figs. 5(c), (d)). From X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra, it has been suggested that the presence of adsorbed ethylene has facilitated the adsorption of Cl− on CER active sites, resulting in increases in average Co oxidation state and electrophilicity of metal site, facilitating the oxidation of Cl− while hindering the recombination of Cl. With similar reactivity, bromine is also widely used as a redox mediator as it is more advantageous than chlorine given the lower thermodynamic potential of bromine evolution reaction (BER), lower competition of BER with OER and higher Br2 solubility in aqueous environment compared to Cl2. For example, Schalck et al. [32] developed a flow-through reactor that employs carbon-based gas diffusion electrode substrates coated with Pt or IrO2 as anode and Ni foam as cathode, resulting in FE of over 75% towards EO production without CO2 and O2 detected. To suppress the formation of 1,2-dibromoethane side product, a backside gas serpentine channel feeding ethylene gas at flow rate of 15 mL min−1 was incorporated to improve the dispersion homogeneity of ethylene over the electrode surface. Besides ethylene and propylene, other alkenes, such as styrene[33,34] and cyclohexene [35] can also undergo halide-mediated partial oxidation. 3.2 H2O2-mediated system Apart from halogens, Ko and coworkers have introduced a photo-electro-heterogeneous catalytic system that uses H2O2 as the redox mediator to epoxidize propylene [36]. As described in Fig. 6(a) , this system consists of three processes, namely (1) photocurrent generation catalyzed by a nanostructured photocatalyst (cobalt-phosphate-loaded BiVO4 or CoPi/BiVO4), (2) selective oxygen reduction reaction to H2O2 on a Co-based electrocatalyst (atomically dispersed Co-N x sites on carbon nanotubes or Co-N/CNT) and (3) non-electrochemical heterogeneous catalysis of propylene epoxidation to PO on titanium silicalite-1 (TS1) zeolite. Like halogens, electrochemically produced H2O2 oxidizes the alkenes chemically in the electrolyte. The selectivity of the H2O2-mediated system is also outstanding, exceeding 97% for PO production at 5 ≤ pH ≤ 8 with almost no by-products. The H2O2-mediated system is more advantageous compared to halide-mediated system as the electrochemically generated H2O2 in the former is a green oxidant that can be reduced to H2O after reaction, while the similarly produced halogen in the latter is hazardous. Nonetheless, the current density and production rate of PO in the sunlight-powered H2O2-mediated system is much lower than the halide-mediated system, and the low current density is largely attributed to the limitation of the photoanode. Simplifying the reactor to an electric-driven cell can remove this limitation and effectively increase the current density. Using SBA-15 as template for impregnation by mixed carbon source including furfuryl alcohol, after calcination and template leaching, optimized mesoporous carbon MC-3 is synthesized and used as cathode for in-situ H2O2 generation [37]. As shown in Fig. 6(b), when oxygen and ethylene are co-fed into alkaline catholyte (0.1 mol L−1 KOH), H2O2 generated from ORR, along with TS-1 catalyst, oxidizes ethylene to EO, which will hydrolyze to EG in alkaline electrolyte. Thus, the selectivity towards EG can reach 99% in this cascade system. However, the H2O2 conversion rate is relatively low, due to the decomposition at the electrode surface. Hence, solid electrolyte (SE) reactor is employed to improve the faradaic efficiency [38]. As shown in Fig. 6(c), OH2 − and proton, generated from ORR on the cathode and OER on the anode respectively, will permeate through anion exchange membrane (AEM) and cation exchange membrane (CEM) respectively under electric field. The H2O2 generated from the combination of OH2 - and proton in solid electrolyte will then transfer to a second reactor for ethylene oxidation to EG. Solid electrolyte reactor can improve the H2O2 utilization and increase the faradaic efficiency towards EG. Furthermore, solid electrolyte can also reduce the demands of electrolyte and simplify the downstream separation and purification process. The superiority of in-situ H2O2 generation over bulk H2O2 solution is reported in Guan's work [37]. The EG yield of the process aided by in-situ H2O2 generation was much higher than that by bulk H2O2 solution at the same concentration. This phenomenon may be attributed to the high local concentration at the electrode/electrolyte interface in the case of the former. Thus, Wang et al. [39] made use of the high local concentration to improve the coupling efficiency of cascade reaction system. As shown in Fig. 6(d), a solid electrolyte reactor is also employed, while TS-1 is directly mixed with solid electrolyte in middle chamber to sufficiently utilize the high H2O2 concentration at the AEM interface. The novel reactor can provide 70% FE and 99.7% EG selectivity, outperforming the system with separated electrocatalytic and thermocatalytic reactors connected in series. The configurations of interfacial and conventional coupling systems are shown in Fig. 6(e). In the interfacially integrated system, the high local concentration generated at the AEM/SE interface leads to higher EG yield than conventional cascade reactors. Although recent progress in H2O2-mediated system shows its promising potential, some issues still require further investigation. The performance stability issue should be thoroughly studied as the stability test has demonstrated a continuous increase in cell voltage with increasing runtime due to the decomposition of the solid electrolyte. Hence, the durability of solid electrolytes in the presence of H2O2 should be further improved. In addition, compared with the HER in halide-mediated system, the anodic OER in H2O2-mediated system is more kinetically sluggish and will increase the cell voltage due to the larger OER overpotential. Thus, it may be helpful to lower cell voltage by using a more effective anode for OER or replacing OER with kinetically favored reaction, such as CER. 4 Conclusions and outlook The key parameters of typical catalytic systems for alkene oxidation are summarized in Fig. 7 . The selectivity and faradaic efficiency (FE) refer to the selectivity and FE of the desired products indicated in the legend. It should be noted that some of the generation rate data, which are not reported in the original articles, are estimated using current density data for explicit comparison. Additionally, the stability of a cell is defined by its reported maximum runtime. As exhibited in the radar plot, most of the reported selectivity data exceed 90% due to the application of the strategies previously discussed. The strategies for selectivity improvement and overoxidation suppression proposed so far can be summarized as follows: (1) modifying geometric structure of the catalytic surface by either surface poisoning or increasing coverage to isolate the reactive sites, (2) regulating electronic structure of the catalytic surface through tuning electronic properties of the surface oxygen in the OAT reaction pathway or adjusting the binding energy of the surface hydroxyl in the OH-correlated reaction pathway, and (3) introducing an electrochemically generated redox mediator that can oxidize the alkenes chemically. The comparison between the direct and indirect electrooxidation systems indicates the superiority of indirect systems in terms of current density and stability over direct systems. Hence, indirect electrooxidation systems exhibit greater potential at the present stage. However, indirect systems generally require higher device complexity and produce hazardous intermediates, which may increase cost and cause environmental concerns. The facile direct electrooxidation systems may outperform the indirect systems if their low current density could be effectively improved. Since the research progress of direct and indirect systems have reached different stages, their problems and challenges are different. For a direct system, it is problematic to increase current density due to the slow kinetics and the parasitic OER. Compared with the facile electrochemical reaction in indirect systems involving either CER or ORR, the oxygenation process in alkene electrochemical oxidation, which is generally considered as the rate determining step (RDS), is not kinetically favored and thus inherently limiting the current density. Worse, as the cell voltage increases, the parasitic OER will dominate, preventing the partial current density of alkene electrooxidation from being increased by simply increasing the cell voltage. Since the RDS of alkene electrooxidation and OER share the intermediates of O* and OH*, the coverage and electronic state of these oxygenated species are vital for boosting reaction kinetics and faradaic efficiency. The relation between these oxygenated species and OER performance has been well investigated, and the formation free energy difference (ΔG O* – ΔG OH*) has been proposed as a descriptor for OER catalyst performance [40], with a volcanic trend between the descriptor and OER overpotential. Thus, similar descriptor for alkene electrooxidation needs to be investigated and clarified so that OER can be suppressed through the tuning of these energetic quantities in catalyst design. As for indirect system, the electrochemical processes for generating redox mediators are well investigated and kinetically favored. Thus, the remaining challenge is to improve the mass transfer of reactants and redox mediators through a rational device design, which will be discussed in this section. To address the abovementioned problems and challenges, further research can be focused on the following perspectives. 4.1 Catalyst modification For direct alkene electrochemical oxidation, the electrocatalysts play a decisive role in its activity and selectivity. Given the low current density and poor stability of the catalysts reported so far, further investigation should be dedicated to the modification of catalysts through doping and alloying, introducing vacancies, optimizing exposed crystal planes, and optimal use of catalyst support. 4.1.1 Doping and alloying Firstly, as previously discussed, different metals embody different electronic or lattice structures as exemplified by the variation of OH binding energy across different dopant metals [24]. Thus, research on structure-activity relationships, which is relatively mature in electrochemical reactions such as OER [41] and CO2RR [42,43], is essential in providing a clear guideline for catalysts design. Besides, modification of metal catalysts, such as doping, can be an efficient way to promote reactivity. By doping foreign metal or metal oxide on the catalytic surface, electronic and/or lattice structures can be tuned through the host-dopant interaction. For instance, Au dopant can alter the OH binding energy on the PdO x surface layer [24] while Ir can tune both the oxidation state and lattice parameter of manganese oxide [22]. Moreover, alloying is also a suitable method to regulate the catalytic properties in designing efficient catalysts [44,45]. 4.1.2 Vacancies Introducing vacancies, including cation and anion vacancies, has been employed to boost catalyst performance for various reactions. Oxygen vacancies, typically generated by adjusting calcination atmosphere and duration, can produce low-coordinated metal sites, which may favor alkene adsorption. Cation vacancies can also create unsaturated oxygen and adjust the electronic state of oxygenated species. Although there are few works mentioning the importance of catalyst vacancies for alkene electrooxidation, vacancies may exist in various catalyst reported so far. Taking Pd for example, it is reported that porous PdO x layer will generate on Pd surface at oxidative potential [24]. The porous PdO x layer itself could contain various vacancies and might have acted as the high reactive sites. Further investigation of catalysts with controlled vacancies may deepen the understanding of alkene electrooxidation and boost the catalytic performance. 4.1.3 Crystal planes Different crystal planes of catalysts exhibit different geometric parameters and electronic structure, therefore deliver different catalytic performance. For instance, the in-plane atomic distance, related with the distance between adsorption sites, can affect the alkene adsorption configuration, such as single-site adsorption or double-site adsorption. As discussed in Section 2.1, the adsorption configuration will affect the selectivity. According to Zeng's work [23], the reactivity and accessibility of oxygenated species also vary on different planes of Ag3PO4. 4.1.4 Support effects Catalysts loaded on support are widely used in chemical industry, and hence, the interaction between the catalyst and the support has also gained significant research interest [46]. Firstly, the catalyst-support interaction can effectively alter the band structure and reactivity of the catalyst. Secondly, some support can also act as a co-catalyst, providing protons or oxygenated species. For instance, metal catalyst can adsorb and activate alkenes, while metal oxide support can facilitate water dissociation and provide oxygenated intermediates, serving as a co-catalyst in a way similar to α-MoC support in Pt/α-MoC in water-gas shift reactions [47]. Additionally, different from thermal heterogeneous catalysis, the electrical conductivity of the support should also be considered in its selection for the electrocatalysts. 4.2 Electrolyte composition Introducing additive into the electrolyte is another way of reversibly modifying the catalyst through adsorption as exemplified by Cl− addition that enhanced the selectivity of catalytic oxidation [10,15,16]. Thus, it is intuitively sensible to explore other possible promotor ions, such as the alkali metal ions, which have been shown to regulate the electric double layer (EDL) [48–50]. Other than inorganic ions, organic ions can also be used to tune the EDL as illustrated by the addition of tetrabutylammonium ion (TBA+) to enhance the hydrophobicity of the Au surface and increase the FE for alkenes epoxidation [21]. Additionally, organic molecular additives, e.g., acetone, which have been used as EDL regulators in aqueous metal ion batteries [51], may also be potential candidates. Moreover, the pH or the proton abundance of the electrolyte may also influence the reaction pathway of alkene electrooxidation. In the catalytic system involving OAT pathway, acetonitrile/water mixed electrolyte, with relatively low proton concentration, is commonly used. By contrast, proton abundant aqueous electrolyte is used in catalytic system where the OH-correlated pathway dominates. Hence, it can be inferred that proton concentration may affect the thermodynamics of oxygenated species and affect the reaction pathways consequently. 4.3 Mechanism investigation Although some strategies are proposed to prevent overoxidation, the mechanism behind each of them is still debatable. For example, in OAT processes, the surface of some catalysts after modification may become either more electrophilic [22] or more nucleophilic [20], but both resulted in better epoxidation selectivity after modification, complicating the relationship between the electrophilicity of the catalytic surface and epoxidation selectivity. To clarify the mechanism of overoxidation prevention, it is necessary to investigate the reaction pathway. The reaction pathway of alkene oxidation can be generally divided into four stages: (1) alkene adsorption on catalyst surface; (2) oxygenated species generation; (3) alkene oxygenation; (4) product desorption. Firstly, the adsorption configuration of alkene remains elusive. Several configurations are proposed so far, including one-site and two-site adsorption of vinyl groups, together with adsorption of allylic carbon or terminal vinyl carbon. Secondly, the effects of abundance and reactivity of oxygenated species on the oxygenation process should be investigated. For instance, performing alkene oxidation on a series of catalysts with different water dissociation activity may provide clues to this puzzle. It is expected that excessively low abundance and reactivity of oxygenated species may limit the oxygenation kinetics, while the opposite may lead to uncontrolled side reaction and even overoxidation. This conjecture can be verified through relevant detailed investigation. Mechanism investigation can be carried out through either theoretical calculations or in-situ or operando characterizations. 4.3.1 Theoretical calculations Density functional theory (DFT) is a widely used basis for computational methods used in investigating reaction mechanisms in chemistry and materials science. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof generalized gradient approximation (PBE-GGA) functional and projector augmented wave (PAW) method are frequently used in recent works of alkene electrooxidation. DFT calculations can provide the free energy of intermediates and search transition state of elementary steps. Thus, the free energy diagrams of different reaction pathways can be presented and compared to deepen the understanding of catalysts selectivity and reactivity. Apart from DFT-based methods, model Hamiltonian method is also employed to model the electrocatalytic reaction. Instead of attempting to solve the full quantum mechanical Schrödinger equation for a complex system, model Hamiltonians focus on capturing the essential physics while ignoring less important details. For instance, Schmickler et al. [52] decomposed the total Hamiltonian into three parts, accounting for reactant molecules, electrode metal and solvent respectively. Due to the approximate nature of Hamiltonians, model Hamiltonian calculations are often computationally less demanding compared to more rigorous methods like DFT or other ab initio calculations. This makes them suitable for studying relatively complicated electrochemical systems. However, the parameters in the Hamiltonian should be obtained from ab initio calculations or molecular dynamic simulations, and the accuracy of the method depends on the rational approximation of Hamiltonians. Moreover, the model Hamiltonian method can also be combined with DFT in different ways [53]. In electrochemical processes, solvent effect plays a decisive role. However, considering computational feasibility, implicit solvation models are generally used in theoretical calculations. By treating the solvent as a continuous medium, implicit solvation models are prone to underestimate solvation effects at the electrode-electrolyte interface [54]. Thus, to precisely model the entire electrochemical interface, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) method that treats solvent molecules explicitly can be employed. AIMD method is a computational technique that simulates the dynamics of atoms and molecules from ab initio calculations (e.g., DFT). However, due to the computational constraints, AIMD method can only simulate over dimensions in order of nanometers (around 100 atoms) for timescales in order of picoseconds (10–100 ps) [55]. Moreover, for higher accuracy, methods beyond DFT can also be used to model the electrochemical processes. For instance, quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) simulation, especially diffusion Monte Carlo (DMC) method, can be used to calculate solvation energy which converged within 0.1 kcal mol−1 [56]. Wave-function-based methods, such as configuration interaction (CI) and coupled cluster (CC), can describe strongly correlated electron systems more accurately than DFT. Many-body perturbation theory (MBPT) can also provide the information on CO adsorption [57] and C–C coupling [58] in CO2RR beyond GGA-level DFT. In short, theoretical calculations can provide thermodynamic and kinetic information for mechanism investigation of alkene electrooxidation, but their accuracy and consistency largely depend on the employed calculation method, making it difficult to compare calculation results from different works. 4.3.2 In-situ or operando characterizations Experimental techniques, especially in-situ or operando characterization techniques, are also indispensable in verifying the predictions on mechanisms made through theoretical calculations. For instance, using in-situ surface-enhanced attenuated total reflection Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR), Liu and coworkers [59] reported the distinct evolution of propylene intermediates on Pd and PdO catalysts under a range of applied potentials. This discovery is made possible with the help of infrared signal enhancement by surface plasmon resonance on the Au film coated on Si prism prior to catalyst coating (Pd/C or PdO) in an internal reflection mode set-up similar to that illustrated in Fig. 8(a) . Alternatively, a large repertoire of catalysts could be studied using external reflection mode, where a thin electrolyte layer is formed by positioning the working electrode near the prism to minimize the traverse distance of the infrared beam to a few micrometers [60]. Even so, to the best of our knowledge, in-situ characterization of time evolution of the intermediates throughout the reaction process has not been reported, which is of great importance in understanding the mechanism and verifying theoretical predictions. In contrast, such characterization has been done for other reactions; for example, there are many mechanistic studies using diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) to present the time evolution of CO2 methanation intermediates [61–64]. Moreover, in-situ XAS has also been widely used to reveal the evolution of catalysts during reaction [65]. This characterization can be carried out in fluorescence mode using a modified electrochemical cell similar to the one displayed in Fig. 8(b), incorporating an X-ray transparent window (which, in this case, is the working electrode) into the standard components of a flow electrolyzer so that incident X-rays and X-ray fluorescence can penetrate the back of the sample-coated working electrode [66]. With the coordination information provided by X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and electronic state information provided by XANES, the real-time interaction between reactants and catalysts can be captured. Additionally, electrochemical mass spectroscopy (EC-MS) is also an effective approach for mechanistic studies. Reaction products generated at the electrode/electrolyte interface can be captured via a probe capillary and analyzed in real-time, providing the operando selectivity information [67]. A possible set-up is depicted in Fig. 8(c), where a capillary with its tip enclosed by a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) membrane was positioned close to a gas diffusion electrode so that the volatile products, such as carbon monoxide and ethanol, can permeate through the PTFE membrane and subsequently be detected by mass spectrometry (MS). Furthermore, some novel methods of MS analysis are also developed. For instance, secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) can be applied to detect the surface intermediates [68]. This can be done using the customized electrochemical reaction cell like the one shown in Fig. 8(d), where a beam of primary ions is emitted to the electrode surface and the secondary ions induced by transient species are released by the surface and detected by the MS. 4.4 Device design For practical application, reactor design and fabrication for alkenes electrooxidation are also indispensable and challenging. This issue seems even more imperative for indirect oxidation since transport of redox mediators is crucial in determining the efficiency of the system. Some device design principles are proposed as follows. 4.4.1 Mass transfer As aforementioned, the reactivity of CER and ORR is relatively high with respect to reactant availability, hence mass transfer has become the rate determining process in the indirect system. It is especially so when the solubility of the reactants is also limited. The Henry's law constants (in water solution) of ethylene and propylene are 0.0047 and 0.0074 mol kg−1 bar−1 respectively (data from NIST Chemistry WebBook). Flow cell has been demonstrated to be efficient in improving mass transfer and increasing the current density. Reactions involving gaseous reactants, such as ORR, can also be improved using gas diffusion electrode (GDE). 4.4.2 Cascade reaction coupling Effective coupling between mediator generating reaction and alkene oxidation reaction is vital in the device design for indirect system. There are three main ways of coupling these reactions: (1) The redox mediators produced in electrolyzer are transferred to another reactor for alkene oxidation. (2) The redox mediators are generated at electrode/electrolyte interface and diffuse to bulk solution to react with alkene feed. (3) In solid electrolyte reactor previously mentioned, H2O2 redox mediators, are generated in-situ at membrane/electrolyte interface and react with alkene flux. Advantage of the third method is to maximize the local concentration of H2O2 at the interface and promote the utilization of H2O2. However, solid electrolyte reactors may also bring the problems of electrolyte decomposition and higher cell voltage. 4.4.3 Product separation Downstream product separation contributes a large portion of overall cost in industry. Thus, upstream consideration of separation in reactor design is of great importance. The alkene oxidation products, generated from electrochemical reactors, are always mixed with electrolyte, which brings extra separation cost. By using solid electrolyte reactors, the alkene oxidation product can be washed out from electrolyzer with pure water, simplifying the separation process. 4.4.4 Cell voltage Lowering the operating cell voltage can effectively reduce the electricity cost. Often, the alkene oxidation reaction is paired with water electrolysis reaction, namely HER and OER. Given the low onset potential of HER and sluggish kinetics of OER, replacing water electrolysis with reactions possessing suitable thermodynamic potential and faster kinetics can reduce the cell voltage and electricity cost. 4.4.5 Membrane selection The membrane should be carefully chosen for each catalytic system. In halide-mediated systems, the absence of membrane [26] or the use of bipolar membrane will cause OH− to escape from catholyte to anolyte, consuming halogen generated in anolyte and therefore reducing the FE towards alkene epoxidation. To address this issue, OH− can be confined within the catholyte by using cation exchange membrane (CEM). Moreover, since that the HER at the cathode is sensitive to Br− poisoning, CEM is also advantageous in preventing Br- from accessing the cathode in bromide-mediated systems [32]. However, it has also been demonstrated that the use of CEM decreases electrolyte conductivity due to depletion of halide ions and countercations in anolyte during operation, increasing the applied potential during continuous reaction, which is unlike AEM that can prevent conductivity loss without significantly reducing its FE [13]. The choice of membrane should be unique to each system depending on its intended function; for example, in the H2O2-mediated integrated system by Ko et al. [36], the photoanode is completely separated from the rest by Nafion proton exchange membrane since its sole function is to generate photocurrent. 4.5 Technoeconomic analysis Technoeconomic analysis (TEA) can demonstrate the conditions under which the electrooxidation of alkenes is profitable (i.e., when the production cost of desired product per metric ton is lower than the market price based on the data from ChemAnalyst). The TEA results shown in Fig. 9 are calculated via the method proposed by Sargent et al. [24] The production cost is considered from the five aspects, including material, operation, separation, electricity and capital cost. The financial profit from the hydrogen generated at the cathode of electrolyzer is also considered. Production cost data have been derived and plotted in Fig. 9 as a function of electricity cost and faradaic efficiency. The white line in each plot represents the present market price of the corresponding product, reflecting the cost of conventional industrial production. The dark blue regions above the white lines indicate that alkene electrooxidation is profitable under the corresponding conditions. The comparison of the results of different products (Figs. 9(a)–(d)) suggests that alkene electrooxidation to PO and PG exhibits larger profitable region than EO and EG, due to the higher market prices of PO and PG. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 9(a), with the electricity cost of 10 cents kWh−1, the FE should reach 60%–70% to make the electrooxidation process profitable. Finally, the TEA results of electrochemical EO production at 10 and 500 mA cm−2 are also presented in Figs. 9(e) and (f). The absence of white line in Fig. 9(e) suggests that there is no profitable region in the plotted range. Even if the FE could reach 100%, the production cost of EO at 10 mA cm−2 is still higher than the market price. When the current density is relatively low, a larger electrolyzer area is needed to achieve the required daily production, which will drastically increase the capital cost. Thus, increasing the current (at certain cell voltage) can improve the economic benefits effectively, as shown in Fig. 9(f). In short, the conversion rate and current density of most reported alkene electrooxidation cells are far from meeting the industrial demands. Hence, we have proposed possibly impactful directions for future research as summarized in Fig. 10 with the goal of enabling the scientific community to enhance both selectivity and catalytic activity of electrochemical alkene oxidation under large-scale electrochemical conditions, thus improving both energy and material efficiencies of such economically impactful reactions. Xiao Ren is an associate research fellow at Peking University. After receiving his Ph.D. (2017) from the Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China, Xiao Ren received postdoctoral training at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (2017–2022). Dr. Ren joined the College of Chemistry and Molecular Engieering of Peking University in 2022. The central paradigm of his research is to develop magnetic materials for electrocatalytic reactions and to study electrochemical reaction processes involving electron spins. The main focus is on the changes in the reaction pathways and the kinetics of chemical reactions in which electron spin is involved. Zhichuan J. Xu is a professor at the School of Materials Science and Engieering, Nanyang Technological University, and a fellow of the Academy of Engineering, Singapore. He is a member of the International Society of Electrochemistry (ISE), the Electrochemistry Society (ECS), and a fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry (FRSC). He serves as the president of ECS Singapore Section. His major research interest is electrocatalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Alkene oxidation is an important industrial process that produces considerable quantities of commodity chemicals, notably ethylene oxide and propylene oxide. However, typical thermal oxidation processes are characterized by harsh reaction conditions and limited selectivity. Thus, electrochemical alternatives with enhanced product selectivity emerge as promising solutions with the possibility of using renewable input energy sources. Herein, we discuss strategies to improve the selectivity of alkene electrooxidation, specifically focusing on the regulation of the geometric and electronic structures of electrocatalysts, as well as the application of mediated indirect oxidation. Furthermore, we also provide an overview of the current challenges and problems requiring further investigation in improving industrial feasibility of electrochemical alkene oxidation.

coredata.dc:title: Selective electrochemical oxidation of alkene: Recent progress and perspectives
